entry.title: Creating sales order through csv file as an input
entry.content:
DATA: lt_lines TYPE TABLE OF string,
lt_columns TYPE TABLE OF string,
lv_line TYPE string,
lv_file TYPE string,
lv_vbeln TYPE bapivbeln-vbeln.

DATA: ls_order_header_in TYPE bapisdhd1,
ls_order_header_inx TYPE bapisdhd1x,
lt_order_items_in TYPE TABLE OF bapisditm,
ls_order_items_in TYPE bapisditm,
lt_order_items_inx TYPE TABLE OF bapisditmx,
ls_order_items_inx TYPE bapisditmx,
lt_order_partners TYPE TABLE OF bapiparnr,
ls_order_partners TYPE bapiparnr,
lt_order_schedules_in TYPE TABLE OF bapischdl,
ls_order_schedules_in TYPE bapischdl,
lt_order_schedules_inx TYPE TABLE OF bapischdlx,
ls_order_schedules_inx TYPE bapischdlx,
lt_return TYPE TABLE OF bapiret2,
ls_return TYPE bapiret2.

PARAMETERS: p_file TYPE rlgrap-filename OBLIGATORY.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_file.
CALL FUNCTION 'F4_FILENAME'
IMPORTING
file_name = p_file.

START-OF-SELECTION.

lv_file = p_file.

CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload
EXPORTING
filename = lv_file
filetype = 'ASC'
CHANGING
data_tab = lt_lines
EXCEPTIONS
OTHERS = 1.

IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE 'Error uploading file' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

LOOP AT lt_lines INTO lv_line FROM 2.
CLEAR: lt_columns.
SPLIT lv_line AT ',' INTO TABLE lt_columns.

READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 1 INTO DATA(doc_type_raw).
DATA(doc_type) = doc_type_raw.
CONDENSE doc_type.
TRANSLATE doc_type TO UPPER CASE.

IF doc_type IS INITIAL.
MESSAGE 'Missing sales document type in CSV line' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

DATA: lv_dummy TYPE c LENGTH 1.
SELECT SINGLE auart INTO @LV_dummy FROM tvak WHERE auart = @DOC_type.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |Sales document type { doc_type } is not defined or not active| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 2 INTO DATA(sales_org).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 3 INTO DATA(distr_chan).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 4 INTO DATA(division).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 5 INTO DATA(itemnum_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 6 INTO DATA(material).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 7 INTO DATA(plant).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 8 INTO DATA(target_qty_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 9 INTO DATA(parnr_numb).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 10 INTO DATA(sched_line_raw).
READ TABLE lt_columns INDEX 11 INTO DATA(req_qty_raw).


DATA: itemnum TYPE bapisditm-itm_number.
itemnum = itemnum_raw.
DATA: target_qty TYPE bapisditm-target_qty.
target_qty = target_qty_raw.
DATA: sched_line TYPE bapischdl-sched_line.
sched_line = sched_line_raw.
DATA: req_qty TYPE bapischdl-req_qty.
req_qty = req_qty_raw.

DATA: ls_dummy TYPE tvakz.
SELECT SINGLE *
INTO @LS_dummy
FROM tvakz
WHERE vkorg = @sales_org
AND vtweg = @distr_chan
AND spart = @division
AND auart = @DOC_type.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |Sales document type { doc_type } is not assigned to sales area { sales_org }/{ distr_chan }/{ division }| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.


SELECT SINGLE kunnr INTO @LV_dummy FROM kna1 WHERE kunnr = @parnr_numb.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE |No customer master record exists for customer { parnr_numb }| TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

ls_order_header_in-doc_type = doc_type.
ls_order_header_in-sales_org = sales_org.
ls_order_header_in-distr_chan = distr_chan.
ls_order_header_in-division = division.

ls_order_header_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_header_inx-doc_type = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-sales_org = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-distr_chan = 'X'.
ls_order_header_inx-division = 'X'.

CLEAR ls_order_partners.
ls_order_partners-partn_role = 'AG'.
ls_order_partners-partn_numb = parnr_numb.
APPEND ls_order_partners TO lt_order_partners.

CLEAR ls_order_partners.
ls_order_partners-partn_role = 'WE'.
ls_order_partners-partn_numb = parnr_numb.
APPEND ls_order_partners TO lt_order_partners.

CLEAR: ls_order_items_in, ls_order_items_inx, ls_order_schedules_in, ls_order_schedules_inx.

ls_order_items_in-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_items_in-material = material.
ls_order_items_in-plant = plant.
ls_order_items_in-target_qty = target_qty.
APPEND ls_order_items_in TO lt_order_items_in.

ls_order_items_inx-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_items_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_items_inx-material = 'X'.
ls_order_items_inx-plant = 'X'.
ls_order_items_inx-target_qty = 'X'.
APPEND ls_order_items_inx TO lt_order_items_inx.

ls_order_schedules_in-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_schedules_in-sched_line = sched_line.
ls_order_schedules_in-req_qty = req_qty.
APPEND ls_order_schedules_in TO lt_order_schedules_in.

ls_order_schedules_inx-itm_number = itemnum.
ls_order_schedules_inx-sched_line = sched_line.
ls_order_schedules_inx-updateflag = 'I'.
ls_order_schedules_inx-req_qty = 'X'.
APPEND ls_order_schedules_inx TO lt_order_schedules_inx.
ENDLOOP.

IF ls_order_header_in-doc_type IS NOT INITIAL.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2'
EXPORTING
order_header_in = ls_order_header_in
order_header_inx = ls_order_header_inx
convert = 'X'
IMPORTING
salesdocument = lv_vbeln
TABLES
return = lt_return
order_items_in = lt_order_items_in
order_items_inx = lt_order_items_inx
order_partners = lt_order_partners
order_schedules_in = lt_order_schedules_in
order_schedules_inx = lt_order_schedules_inx.

READ TABLE lt_return INTO ls_return WITH KEY type = 'E'.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_ROLLBACK'.
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_return ).
ELSEIF lv_vbeln IS NOT INITIAL.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
EXPORTING
wait = 'X'.
DATA(lt_output) = VALUE stringtab(
( |Sales Order created successfully.| )
( |Sales Order Number: { lv_vbeln }| )
).
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_output ).
ELSE.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_ROLLBACK'.
CL_DEMO_OUTPUT=>DISPLAY( lt_return ).
ENDIF.
ELSE.
MESSAGE 'No valid data to process' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

 

This ABAP report enables bulk creation of SAP Sales Orders by reading data from a CSV file uploaded from the user's local system. It leverages the standard BAPI BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 to create sales orders in SAP S/4HANA or ECC systems, making it ideal for mass data upload scenarios such as migrations, testing, or initial data loads.

Aceleradores/Herramientas de Side-by-Side Extensibility

Descripci√≥n: SAP Build es una plataforma de desarrollo de aplicaciones sin c√≥digo que permite a los usuarios finales crear aplicaciones personalizadas que se integran con SAP Cloud ERP. Facilita la creaci√≥n de aplicaciones m√≥viles y web sin necesidad de conocimientos t√©cnicos avanzados.

Cu√°ndo usarlo: Ideal para usuarios finales que necesitan crear aplicaciones personalizadas r√°pidamente y sin la necesidad de codificaci√≥n extensiva.

Ventajas:

  • Versatilidad: Permite la creaci√≥n de aplicaciones sin necesidad de conocimientos de programaci√≥n, as√≠ como la opci√≥n de integrar el desarrollo de c√≥digo. 
  • Rapidez: Facilita la creaci√≥n r√°pida de aplicaciones personalizadas.

2. BTP Partner Reference App

Descripci√≥n: BTP Partner Reference App es una herramienta que permite a los partners de SAP crear y desplegar aplicaciones de extensi√≥n directamente en SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform). Estas aplicaciones est√°n dise√±adas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, facilitando la integraci√≥n y el mantenimiento.

Desde In-App Extensions para cambios r√°pidos y sencillos, hasta Side-by-Side Extensions para necesidades m√°s complejas, cada tipo de extensi√≥n tiene su prop√≥sito y ventajas. Los aceleradores/herramientas como BTP Partner Reference App, Joule for Developers, SAP Build, Multi-Off Delivery y Scalable Delivery ofrecen herramientas y soluciones que facilitan la extensibilidad y personalizaci√≥n de SAP Cloud ERP.

Espero que esta gu√≠a te haya proporcionado una comprensi√≥n clara de las opciones de extensibilidad disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP, las herramientas y te permita aprovechar al m√°ximo las capacidades de extender esta soluci√≥n. ¬°No dudes en explorar m√°s para descubrir c√≥mo estas herramientas pueden ayudar a tu empresa a alcanzar nuevos niveles de eficiencia y personalizaci√≥n!

entry.title: End-to-End Shell Copy Scenario in Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM) 1.0
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Step 1: System Export
  • 1. Download the Latest SWPM:
  • 2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario
  • 3. Set Source System Parameters
  • 4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0
  • 5. Transfer Export Directory
  • Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host)
  • 1. Prepare Target Database
  • 2. Install ASCS Instance
  • 3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries
  • 4. Import Database Shell Instance
  • 5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS)
  • Step 3: Post-Copy Activities
  • Tips & Recommendations
  • Useful Links

 

Introduction

Shell Copy is a new scenario introduced in SWPM 1.0 to support digital transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.  For more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC].  

The shell copy scenario helps you prepare an SAP ERP shell system containing all Dictionary and Repository objects and all Customizing - while excluding application data. For more insights, please see the introductory blog: [Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario]. 

Below, you'll find an example workflow that demonstrates a typical Shell Copy procedure using SWPM 1.0 for SAP ERP 6.0 EHP8 on Linux. The process consists of three main phases: system export, system provisioning, and post-copy steps.  

IMPORTANT: Always consult the latest SAP product documentation and Shell Copy Guide specific to your operating system and database platform. Review and apply all relevant SAP Notes before starting the Shell Copy scenario on your landscape. 

 

Step 1: System Export

1. Download the Latest SWPM:  
  • Obtain the latest SWPM 1.0 for NW higher than 7.0x SAR file supporting Shell Copy from SAP Software Center. 
  • Review prerequisites: "Running Software Provisioning Manager". 
2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario 
  • In the Product Catalog, select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 ‚Üí EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP ‚Üí <DB Type> ‚Üí Shell Copy ‚Üí Source System ‚Üí Database Instance Shell Export 

 

3. Set Source System Parameters 
  • Confirm or enter the path to the SAP ECC profile folder 

  • Enter <sid> adm password when prompted. 

 

  • Provide the DDIC user‚Äôs password in client 000 (needed for online preparation). 

4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0 
  • In the Shell Copy scenario, Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0 replaces Migration Monitor for database migration. 

  • Specify the export directory path where SWPM will extract and run SUM. 
  • Download and provide the latest SUM 2.0 archive from the SAP Software Center. 

  • Confirm the ‚ÄúParameter Summary‚Äù dialog to trigger exports. 
5. Transfer Export Directory 
  • When export is completed, copy the entire export directory to the target host (including SUM and data). 

Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host) 

1. Prepare Target Database 
  • Set up the target database per the installation guide for SAP ERP 6.0. Under ‚ÄúProduct Release‚Äù, make sure that you select ‚ÄúSAP NetWeaver 7XX-based‚Äù. 
  • Tip: Review and apply required SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
    that resolve known issues. 
2. Install ASCS Instance 
  • Start SWPM 1.0 on the target and choose:‚Ä®SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 ‚Üí EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP ‚Üí <DB Type> ‚Üí Shell Copy ‚Üí Target System ‚Üí ASCS Instance 
  • The SAP system ID (SAPSID) must remain the same between source and target (e.g., if source is SC1, target must also be SC1). 
  • In that example we provide a Master Password for all system users such, e.g. <sid>adm, SAPService<SAPSID>. If you did not create the operating system users manually before the installation, the Software Provisioning Manager creates them with the common Master Password. If users are not pre-created, SWPM will create them. 
  • For master password requirements, refer to he SAP System Parameters section of the installation guide. 
3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries 
  • SWPM will prompt for SAPEXE Kernel archive and the SAP Host Agent binary files - have them ready. 
4. Import Database Shell Instance 
  • On the target DB host, launch SWPM and select:‚Ä®SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 ‚Üí EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP ‚Üí <DB Type> ‚Üí Shell Copy ‚Üí Target System ‚Üí Database Shell Instance 
  • For standard installation (all instances on one host), /sapmnt/ is local and SWPM will detect profile directory. 
  • Use the previously set master password and <sid>adm password 
  • Enter the same DBSID as used in the source system.
  • Provide the required SAP Kernel resources
  • Specify the SUM export directory path you copied earlier. 
  • Note: If changing CPU architecture (e.g., Windows to Linux), provide the appropriate SUM.SAR for the new OS on the target system

  • Address any DB-specific dialogs without making unsupported changes to the DB layer. 
5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS) 
  • Launch SWPM and choose:‚Ä®SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 ‚Üí EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP ‚Üí <DB Type> ‚Üí Shell Copy ‚Üí Target System ‚Üí Stub Primary Application Server Instance 
  • Specify the instance profile folder. 
  • Use the previously set master password. 
  • Provide archives for SAPEXE, IGSEXE, and IGSHelper as requested. 
  • Address any DB-specific dialogs. 
  • Once the PAS instance installation has been completed, the Shell ABAP system should be up and running. 

Step 3: Post-Copy Activities 

The last step is to prepare the Shell ERP system as described in the Follow-Up Activities section of the Shell Copy Guide for your operating system and platform. 

Tips & Recommendations 
  • Prepare required SAP Notes in advance to avoid interruptions. 
  • Use the latest supported versions of SWPM and SUM. 
  • Avoid DB layer changes between source and target unless explicitly supported by SAP. 
  • Master passwords should comply with all OS-level security policies. 
Useful Links 
  • SAP Software Center 
  • Shell Copy Guide 
  • Post-Copy Activities 
  • SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
  • ‚ÄúReducing DB Size of SAP ERP systems via Shell Copy Scenario‚Äù 

By following these steps, you can efficiently perform a shell copy of your SAP ERP landscape using SWPM 1.0 and SUM 2.0.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading üòä Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let‚Äôs be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company‚Äôs workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, and it is not a technology that must be considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI ‚Äì to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn‚Äôt it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

 Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism üòä Guessing the comments like, ‚Äúthat is not for productive environment‚Äù, ‚ÄúDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses‚Äù and many other sharp negatives. But let‚Äôs move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I‚Äôve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let‚Äôs implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order‚Äôs header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: SAP Landscape Strategy in the Era of Managed Cloud and AI
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs digital-first world, enterprises face intense pressure to operate faster, leaner, and smarter. Emerging technologies like cloud computing, AI, and next-generation ERP systems are transforming how businesses run. Amid this change, SAP landscape consolidation presents a complex challenge, requiring close alignment between business and IT. While it can simplify IT environments, reduce costs, and enable intelligent automation, many organizations struggle to find the right approach. This article aims to demystify the topic, offering executives a clear framework to evaluate options, make informed decisions, and maximize value through an effective instance strategy.

The Case for Landscape Consolidation

Historically, most organizations have accumulated fragmented SAP landscapes through mergers, acquisitions, and regional growth‚Äîeach business unit running its own version of ‚Äúthe truth.‚Äù These siloed environments inflate total cost of ownership, complicate reporting, and slow decision-making. Consolidation directly addresses this by unifying systems into a single, standardized architecture that delivers agility, transparency, and control. From the 1990s to the 2000s, technological limits‚Äîparticularly hardware capacity‚Äîonce made global system consolidation impractical. But today, with exponential advancements in computing power, cloud scalability, and tools like SAP‚Äôs Unicode-based Business Suite and Country Versions, technology is no longer the barrier. The question is no longer can we consolidate, but why haven‚Äôt we yet?

The financial argument is equally compelling. Organizations that have consolidated SAP landscapes typically achieve measurable cost reductions across key operational areas‚Äîaround 20% in IT operations, 15% in end-user services, 10% in application development, and 8% in maintenance and administration. These savings compound over time, freeing up capital for innovation and strategic growth. More importantly, a unified system landscape enhances global visibility, and accelerates decision-making at scale. For CIOs and CFOs alike, landscape consolidation is not merely an IT optimization‚Äîit‚Äôs a business transformation lever that drives sustainable efficiency, competitive advantage, and enterprise-wide value creation.

Beyond Systems: Why Process Harmonization Matters

System consolidation alone doesn‚Äôt guarantee efficiency. Without harmonized business processes, organizations often find that operational inconsistencies persist even after technical consolidation is achieved. In other words, system consolidation without process harmonization is suboptimal from a total cost of ownership (TCO) perspective.

According to SAP Value Group benchmarks, the typical cost distribution for enterprise systems is approximately 20% hardware, 20% software, 42% development, application support, help desk, and end-user training, 12% system and data management, and 8% other. The largest cost category ‚Äî development and support ‚Äî can only be reduced when process variants and customizations are minimized through harmonization and standardization. For this reason, almost all companies that embark on global implementation or consolidation programs also pursue global harmonization of their business processes.

However, while IT organizations often recognize the benefits of harmonization and may attempt to implement global templates ‚Äúbehind the scenes,‚Äù true process harmonization cannot be successfully driven by IT alone. It is not a one-time technical exercise, but a continuous business-led transformation that requires executive sponsorship, strong governance, and a clear change management strategy. The business must own and drive harmonization initiatives, defining clear objectives that align with organizational strategy. When processes are harmonized, they enable consistent data, standardized workflows, and measurable outcomes ‚Äî all of which are essential foundations for scaling intelligent automation and realizing the full efficiency potential of system consolidation.

Ultimately, while IT cost savings from ERP instance consolidation may reach 25%, the true value lies in achieving global visibility, standardized processes, and improved business coordination‚Äîbenefits attainable only when system consolidation is paired with process harmonization.

How Cloud & AI Have Evolved SAP Landscape Strategy

SAP has long been at the forefront of enterprise transformation. At the core of this evolution is a shift in how enterprises view their landscapes ‚Äî not just as technical environments but as strategic enablers. The pyramid structure in the diagram below highlights how harmonization and standardization at the strategic level (vision, strategy, and processes) are driving the reduction of system complexity at the operational level (infrastructure and projects). This reflects SAP‚Äôs broader goal: simplifying, standardizing, and automating across every layer of the enterprise stack.

The right side of the diagram captures how landscape simplification and consolidation have evolved in a cloud-first era. Hyperscalers have made on-premise (non-SAP managed) operations more flexible and efficient; however, the cost advantages of cloud operations are making regional or local systems increasingly attractive. At the same time, geopolitical disruptions and growing requirements for data localization are prompting enterprises to reconsider their global architectures. As business units evolve, organizations need modular IT landscapes that can adapt quickly to changing market dynamics. Finally, ongoing mergers and acquisitions are further challenging global IT solutions to remain agile and responsive.

While the drivers of change have evolved, the case for landscape consolidation remains strong ‚Äî especially when considering the transition to SAP S/4HANA as it presents a unique opportunity for enterprises to re-evaluate and modernize their environments. In the new cloud-first era, the key takeaway is that process harmonization alone is not sufficient. True transformation requires a commitment to standardizing on SAP best practices and processes. Only by combining harmonization with standardization can businesses fully realize the benefits of consolidation.

Landscape Options for SAP Process Harmonization

When consolidating SAP systems, organizations can choose among several landscape options that balance process harmonization with flexibility and deployment complexity. The Single Instance Strategy represents the highest degree of process harmonization, enforcing identical procedures and configurations globally within one system. The Virtual Single Instance Strategy, often called the full template approach, also targets global standardization but allows multiple production systems connected to a common template. This option achieves strong alignment across regions but requires significant upfront effort to harmonize processes and design a robust governance framework to maintain consistency.

In contrast, the Template + Multiple Development Systems Strategy (partial template) introduces a global development system for common configurations, while local development systems handle regional adaptations. This approach lowers harmonization effort but increases deployment and maintenance complexity, as changes must be coordinated and synchronized across environments. Finally, the Multiple Development Systems Strategy allows the greatest local flexibility but risks divergence without disciplined governance. Companies without adequate oversight often drift from standardized templates toward independent, inconsistent environments‚Äîundermining the benefits of consolidation.

Strong governance and well-defined change management are essential for success, regardless of the chosen model. SAP recommends establishing detailed governance and leveraging tools like SAP Solution Manager Cross-Landscape Distribution (XLD) to manage common configurations and automate object distribution.

Why Template Strategies are so Attractive

Template strategies are appealing because they balance the competing priorities of standardization and flexibility. While a fully harmonized, single global instance delivers high transparency, operational synergies, and seamless information sharing, it can also demand significant coordination and restrict local agility. Conversely, a highly decentralized landscape with multiple independent systems enables rapid local responses, minimizes coordination overhead, and preserves legacy practices‚Äîbut often sacrifices integration, efficiency, and visibility. In practice, the optimal point rarely lies at either extreme.

A well-governed global template represents the ‚Äúbest of both worlds.‚Äù It establishes common core processes and configurations across the enterprise, creating a unified baseline for reporting, governance, and automation, while still allowing local adaptations to meet regional or business-specific needs. This balance optimizes net benefits‚Äîachieving substantial harmonization without paralyzing flexibility. Organizations adopting this model can scale globally with consistency and efficiency, yet remain agile enough to evolve with market demands and regulatory changes.

Driving Alignment and Change Across the Enterprise

Consolidation initiatives only succeed when the business‚Äînot IT alone‚Äîowns the vision. CIOs and CFOs must jointly champion the strategy, aligning executive priorities and translating technical goals into tangible business outcomes. Indecision is worse than a decision; leaders must either commit fully to consolidation or abandon it. A half-hearted approach breeds confusion, wasted effort, and political resistance.

The business must first define why consolidation matters‚Äîwhether to streamline operations, reduce costs, or enable digital scalability‚Äîbefore any meaningful strategy discussions can occur. The opportunity cost of doing nothing far outweighs the risks of action. Inaction means missed chances for efficiency, growth, and long-term competitiveness. A strategic approach must therefore focus on optimizing performance through technology and process enhancements to achieve sustainable growth and market advantage.

Every consolidation journey ultimately aligns with one of three business scenarios. In the ‚ÄúWinner Takes It All‚Äù model, a larger entity absorbs a smaller one, prioritizing cost avoidance, risk reduction, and speed‚Äîoften driven by politics rather than process optimization. The ‚ÄúBest of Both Worlds‚Äù scenario emerges when merging entities are similar in size, each seeking to retain its systems and approaches, leading to cherry-picking, high complexity, and potential deadlock without decisive executive leadership. Lastly, the ‚ÄúCluster Selection‚Äù approach consolidates around relatively autonomous units, balancing flexibility and structure while reducing political tension. Each model carries trade-offs, but success in any of them depends on clear decision-making, consistent leadership, and an unwavering focus on the business rationale behind consolidation.

Decision-Making Framework: From Strategy to Execution

For complex organizations, making the right consolidation decisions can feel daunting. A structured, business-driven framework ensures that each decision is anchored in strategy, not convenience. Consolidation must begin with clarity on why a new landscape is required. The business must first define its objectives‚Äîwhether to improve visibility, reduce costs, or enable standardized global operations‚Äîand communicate the factors influencing consolidation to the IT organization. These include operational pain points, integration challenges, and the cultural readiness for adopting a global business model. Without this alignment and clear ownership, consolidation efforts risk becoming purely technical exercises detached from business value.

Once business intent is clear, IT and business leaders should collaboratively translate it into a practical landscape strategy and design. Together, they develop up to four viable landscape scenarios that reflect different balances of harmonization and flexibility. Each scenario is then assessed through an agreed-upon set of evaluation criteria‚Äîsuch as scalability, governance, deployment complexity, total cost of ownership, and change management impact‚Äîwith weighted importance assigned to both business and operational priorities. A structured decision process, often supported by workshops or governance boards, leads to a collective vote on the final landscape design and instance strategy. From there, a project roadmap can be established to guide execution. By following this disciplined approach, organizations ensure decisions are data-driven, collaborative, and sustainable‚Äîlaying the foundation for long-term enterprise value creation and true business-IT alignment.

Turning Consolidation into Competitive Advantage

The rise of SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Private and Public Editions), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and Business Data Cloud (BDC) has transformed how organizations approach landscape consolidation. These platforms provide the flexibility to run modern SAP systems across hybrid and multi-cloud environments, supported by AI-driven insights and automation.

SAP‚Äôs Business AI capabilities now automate repetitive tasks, predict trends, and enable intuitive, conversational interactions with business systems. By embedding intelligence directly into processes, organizations gain speed, accuracy, and foresight ‚Äî shifting their focus from data collection to decision-making.

SAP landscape consolidation is no longer a technical exercise ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic imperative for building an intelligent, agile enterprise. By harmonizing systems and processes, embracing cloud-native tools, and integrating AI, businesses position themselves for operational excellence and continuous innovation. In an era where speed and intelligence define market leaders, the organizations that master landscape consolidation today will define the intelligent enterprises of tomorrow.

Consider SAP Customer Advisory

If your organization is planning or evaluating an SAP instance strategy, our team at SAP Customer Advisory can help. We offer tailored guidance to align your architecture vision with business goals, accelerate transformation, and maximize value creation. Connect with me on LinkedIn to explore how we can shape your SAP strategy together.

Maturity Levels Explained

The Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP is designed to provide organizations with a clear, current snapshot of how to utilize SAP BTP effectively. 4. Scalable Execution: Here, SAP BTP is deployed reliably at scale, driving innovation across the organization. This stage reflects a higher level of maturity, where the platform is not only used but also leveraged to achieve strategic business objectives.

5. Center of Excellence: The pinnacle of SAP BTP maturity, this level signifies that the organization recognizes SAP BTP as a strategic driver of its business. Enterprise architecture, operations, and delivery capabilities are optimized around SAP BTP, fostering an environment of continuous innovation.

The Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP serves as a valuable tool for organizations to evaluate their current standing and plan for future growth. It not only aids in identifying areas for improvement but also provides actionable insights to enhance the platform's utilization, ultimately supporting the organization's continuous process of evolution and thriving in the digital landscape.

entry.content:
Author: Allan Soo

Introduction

Healthcare public sector procurement spend is among the largest across the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). In 2021, 31.9% of all public procurement spend touches on public healthcare and infrastructure [1]. Nearly 75% of public spend on healthcare came from taxpayers [2]. With an ageing population and a shrinking taxpayer base, governments across the world are grappling with these fiscal challenges. One solution is to deploy effective spend management, procurement solutions across cost-intensive sectors of the economy to keep costs down.

Figure depicting the percentage government expenditure across the OECD-EU countries for 2023 [3]. Public sector procurement across the OECD-EU markets was 14.7% (2023), an increase of 0.9% compared to 2019.  

Why an effective, public procurement platform is crucial for public healthcare and governments?

Public procurement in healthcare is one of the most regulated forms of purchasing dealing with hospitals, pharmacies, and qualified suppliers. This requires complex compliance to purchasing pharmaceutical ingredients, chemicals and other regulated products to be compliant to public healthcare agencies. An example is the procurement of surgical implants and tools which must comply with the Therapeutic Goods Association (TGA) and other dangerous goods regulations.

Healthcare public procurement is becoming a significant challenge for governments worldwide due to factors such as an ageing population, rising deficits and total debts, the high costs of running healthcare facilities, and increased health and safety regulations.

Track spend and compliance across cost-intensive healthcare segments by different categories with SAP Ariba Category Management, SAP Ariba Intake Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle Performance Management

SAP Ariba Category Management gives public sector healthcare purchasers the tools to track spend goals on their most cost-intensive areas of their agency including high-tech equipment, specialized hospital beds, pharmaceutical purchases and more.

The solution gives public healthcare purchasers the option to manage supplier performance and track these against budgets, manage funds and investments assigned and set to them by the government.

The solution also offers customers a 360-degree visibility into the supplier‚Äôs healthcare certifications and qualifications, making sure that they comply to directives and maximize compliance across all purchases made for the public facilities. For example, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) license for Australia, Wholesale Distribution Authorisation for EU suppliers supplying medicinal products, and Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency certification for medicinal product manufacturing in the United Kingdom.

Adverse events can then be monitored using SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance Management to manage supplier risks appropriately. 3rd party data such as D&B can give government buyers additional intelligence on the market risk of that supplier such as sustainability, supply chain exposure, and aid in calculating inherent and residual risk scoring‚Ä¶and so on. Up to 25 custom risk scores can be applied to the healthcare supplier in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Renegotiate and manage multiple quotes across healthcare suppliers to drive cost savings with finance

To keep costs down, buyers have the ability with SAP Ariba Sourcing and Procurement for Public Sector in SAP S/4HANA, to manage different quotes and renegotiate prices with existing suppliers to obtain better deals. For example, evaluating the procurement of multiple MRI and X-ray machines, and different existing drug prices to encourage better competition between pharmaceutical suppliers to drive down prices.

Buyers can take advantage of the SAP Taulia Private Cloud solution with SAP S/4HANA and Dynamic Discounting feature where fast, early account payable transactions towards suppliers can lead to discounted cash savings that yield improved bottom line benefits for public healthcare finance customers.

Connect SAP Ariba Sourcing and SAP Ariba Buying solutions to the SAP S/4HANA ERP for high-level spend management and monitoring

Go beyond purchasing and ordering with high-level dashboard spend visibility [4] to track the list of purchase orders with SAP Ariba Central Procurement with SAP Ariba Buying (3EN) and SAP Ariba Buying, with guided buying capabilities (2NV) into SAP S/4HANA. Easily track the process flow of your purchases and export accounting documents to SAP finance and accounting solutions. Use three-way matching against invoice, purchase order and goods receipt to ensure that cost information is accurate. Request quotes from suppliers, allocate budget and discuss on pricing terms.

One highly relevant area for this is the operational procurement of medical apparel, protective equipment, gloves and face masks. You as the buyer want the tools to negotiate with suppliers on favorable pricing terms, sort price lists in Catalogs available over the SAP Business Network, and see the list of purchase orders, invoices and goods receipts in one place. You can set estimated budgets throughout the quotation process and track how far below under the target price you are able to get the costs down to attain cost savings.

Figure showing SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing solution where healthcare purchasers can track how far below taxpayer funded budget they can obtain when purchasing medical supplies like gloves.

With these solutions, healthcare public sector buyers and public finance can move away from matching for accuracies and scrutinize cost details on these items and work collaboratively with other departments to find alternative suppliers and products that offer cheaper and better-quality substitutes.  

Leverage AI solutions for contracts management

SAP Ariba Contract Intelligence by Icertis SolEx has contract authoring capabilities that are bolstered by AI to automate much of the clause generation that is in line with the public healthcare industry and to drive compliance. Examples can include authoring in sustainability criteria, medical manufacturing license requirements from suppliers, and assigning responsibilities on direct suppliers and their affiliates. By automating the contract lifecycle, lead times can be reduced and anomalies within contract clauses can be detected and flagged for risk mitigation. The solution helps users identify contract leakage risks to prevent cost blowouts and put boundaries on spend conditions for public healthcare purchases. Risk scores on suppliers can be imported from SAP Ariba Supplier Risk to SAP Ariba Contracts to guide contract awarding decisions so that risk-aware awarding decisions can be made. Managing suppliers is part of the public sector procurement responsibility to ensure that government healthcare agencies continue receiving the best outcomes for the budget they are given with the right contracts in place.

Put cost guardrails on healthcare goods and services procured

With WK value contracts [5] in SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba Contracts [6] users can set guardrails against overspending on suppliers. Given that in healthcare settings the quantity of goods can be non-negotiable, SAP Ariba Contracts offers the flexibility to adjust quantity (through quantity contracts) and assign other attributes such as discounts on purchased goods through supplier collaboration and negotiations. Buyers can set cost parameters on the value contracts and publish it through the Cloud Integration Gateway to SAP S/4HANA. Purchase cost data can then be ingested by finance solutions to monitor and act on the financial performance of the health agency.

Smart Peppol invoicing with SAP S/4HANA and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

With eInvoicing solutions offered with SAP Documents and Reporting Compliance (cloud edition) within S/4HANA ERP Public Cloud Edition, SAP Business Network via SAP Integration Suite, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management - Peppol compliant documents can be exchanged to help government healthcare sectors align with eInvoicing compliance requirements or eliminate the use of physical paper. Eliminating physical paperwork and complying to Peppol eInvoicing means enhancing fraud-prevention systems in place to build trust with the public and install financial protections, improves productivity and minimizes errors in costing amounts.  Peppol is used by over 40 countries worldwide for business-to-government transactions, and is becoming a standardized, secure method of receiving invoices from the private sector supplier base by government agencies. Public hospitals and other healthcare agencies can examine and analyze invoice costs based on the high-fidelity information supplied electronically within the system, making it easily auditable for finance.

AI-driven Statement of Work (SOW) creations in SAP Fieldglass to alleviate workloads and focus on the things that matter

Minimize admin work and hire contractors to help comply to a variety of laws during the SOW creation process. Use the GenAI solution at SAP to identify opportunities to control costs during the SOW creation and reduce document creation times by about 71% by inputting titles, summaries and extracting data from PDF documents. With freed-up workloads, users can focus on the quality, risk and service traits of the contract (such as proper skills matching for best labour productivity outcomes). An example includes SOW creation for biohazardous health waste disposal services and scoping the boundaries of work, and clearly stating what services are in and out of scope and using SOW teams feature to collaborate with non-procurement colleagues on budget planning with finance that addresses high-spend service categories.

Improved SOW rates negotiation and cost management features on contracted services

Service buyers can negotiate for better rates post-agreement, automate offboarding signatures to cease spend, ensure hours worked are fulfilled by the contractors, reallocation of unspent SOW funds back to master SOW, inactivate cost centers when they are no longer used, and trigger alerts when rates vary away from agreed ones. These are features that are offered by SAP Fieldglass to service buyers in public healthcare settings to put a lid on costs.

Picture this, you need to onboard technicians to provide maintenance and calibration services for the complex equipment that the hospital has. Your rates need to be specified clearly, and any pay deviations need to be notified to the service buyer, clear start-end dates for the services and so on need to be in the SOW for legal reasons. You use the GenAI feature to produce an SOW quickly, double check the contents of this document, and have the work order issued. Skills are clearly specified for the job to minimize lead times onsite, and the best labour-hire is made. Therefore, costs are controlled, and the best productivity is obtained for maintenance work at the hospital.

Support green procurement practices

SAP Ariba Sourcing integrates with the suite of SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP sustainability solutions to drive green procurement practices across the public healthcare sector. Given that Scope 3 contributes to around 79% of total carbon emissions [7] for this sector across the OECD markets, governments can use SAP tools to drive sustainable procurement practices on their direct suppliers. Examples including procuring gloves with a low product carbon footprint, high recycled content, and rubber data to ensure that illegal deforestation has not contributed to its production.

Alongside SAP Ariba Supplier Management, SAP Fieldglass and SAP Ariba Contracts, public healthcare sectors can manage risk appropriately and enforce sustainability practices and compliance on suppliers and contractors. This includes due diligence screening solutions on a supplier‚Äôs human rights and deforestation records, having the right sustainability credentials, and embedding sustainability due diligence into the core operational and strategic sourcing processes from procurement to the ERP environment. Given the mandates that governments must meet for their own net-zero, human rights and material circularity directives - SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP ERP Sustainability solutions provide a comprehensive suite of products to drive decarbonization and compliance in the public healthcare space. Partner solutions on the SAP app store can be used to enrich supplier data with sustainability scores and other external intel.

Tap into the SAP Spend Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud solution for rich data reporting on procurement spend

Enrich healthcare spend data with other SAP Business Data Cloud products to gain deeper insights into the entire healthcare organization‚Äôs finance and spend data. SAP Spend Intelligence offers customers a large variety of data products it can ingest. For example, sustainability, risk, contract leakages and off-contract purchase order spend.  By providing strategic and operational insights into a public healthcare‚Äôs spend, buyers can optimize for and eliminate out non-compliance and uses AI and machine learning to automatically allocate spend categories neatly for interpretation. SAP Joule can be employed to clean and present cluttered data in a meaningful way that helps drive high-level decision-making processes which maximizes healthcare spend impacts and cuts down maverick and unwanted tail spend.

Conclusion

SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass and SAP S/4HANA ERP solutions provide finance and spend management solutions that offer customers the tools to keep up to date with the latest innovations in driving cost savings, optimize spend, manage down risks, reduce fraud and work collaboratively with public sector finance teams in government. Given the significance of public healthcare sectors across developed markets, innovative procurement spend management solutions play a key role in controlling costs in a high-expenditure industry. For years to come, healthcare expenses are projected to increase with an ageing population, rising deficits and living cost challenges.

This requires a comprehensive, suite of solutions for the public sector that leverages best-of-breed AI and solution offerings that advance the modernization of public sector procurement and finance operations. Governments have a responsibility to foster trust, comply to own directives, address fiscal challenges across the economy for the wellbeing of citizens, and deliver services cost-effectively to the public.

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (1/3): Impactful Preparation and Demo
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens G√∂tz

Rolling out a global S/4HANA core template is never just a technical exercise ‚Äì it is rather a broader cultural shift for an organization. It‚Äôs the pivotal point where local expertise meets a standard global vision. The first two steps of the Fit2Standard approach - Local Units‚Äô Preparation and the System Demo ‚Äì carry more weight than they seem at the first glance.   

Handled well, these phases set the project on right track, highly reducing rework later in template validation and adoption. Shall they be handled, however, poorly, they create confusion, misalignment across an enterprise and weeks of unnecessary follow-up.

So, how does the right preparation phase look like for a successful Fit2Standard approach?

Local Units‚Äô Preparation: Four Weeks to Shape the Entire Rollout

The rollout begins with the preparation, which is not just an administrative warm-up. It is the point where each unit equips itself to speak with clarity and authority during the entire Fit2Standard implementation.

From the Fit2Standard roadmap (see image above), this phase seems simple and lean embracing onboarding, local information collection, and local team set-up. Nevertheless, in practice, it is much more strategic.

Local teams bring requirements, legal constraints, operational differences, tax rules and real-world transaction examples ‚Äì all the components that the program team can never know fully in advance. If this information is incomplete or delivered at a later stage, every subsequent Fit2Standard phases will be at risked or slowed down.

A strong preparation embraces the following five factors which have to be carried out in a consistent manner:

Upfront nomination of the correct team: a small, empowered group ‚Äî a local process owner, local finance/operations SME and an IT contact, ‚Äî becomes the voice of the unit / entity. This group of people are active decision-makers.

Creation of a solid basis: statutory rules and requirements, sample transactions, org charts, current process documentation, all create a solid basis for later comparison and meaningful usage.

Effective usage of the preparation period:  it provides the local teams to find a shared language with the central team through elevating the time for self-study, intro sessions, training on the S/4 Connect platform.

The System Demo: Bridging Local Reality and the Standard Framework

Following the preparation, comes the moment everyone is waiting for: the first live look at the S/4HANA core template.

In the Fit2Standard timeline, the System Demo is the bridge between preparation and analysis ‚Äî a shared stage where local expectations meet the standard design.

The Demo Workshop is designed to give the participants insight into the system landscape and infrastructure, end-to-end template processes and transaction flows.

In order to make the demo sessions rewarding for the entire subsequent rollout, it is important to secure a smooth collaboration between the local teams and the project team. Crucial factors of success are:

Realistic, Business-Ready Data

A demo is only credible if it uses meaningful master and transactional data. Realistic data allows users to recognize their business, trust the system behavior, and validate processes accurately.

Clear, Story-Driven Scenarios

A strong demo follows a real end-to-end business scenario‚Äînot isolated transactions. A narrative (‚Äúday in the life‚Äù) helps stakeholders understand how S/4HANA supports and improves their actual workflows.

Fully Prepared and Rehearsed Delivery

The system, roles, configuration, and presenters must be fully prepared. A smooth, well-rehearsed demo builds confidence; a disorganized one generates doubt and resistance.

Capturing Decisions and Actionable Outcomes

The value of a demo lies in its outputs. Clear decisions and assigned actions ensure the demo directly drives design progress instead of becoming a passive show-and-tell.

The demo is the moment when the abstract template becomes tangible for local teams. With proper preparation, teams move from questioning whether the model fits their context to identifying the areas that will require adjustments for their specific case. This mindset shift is the core of Fit2Standard.

Start Strong for a Smooth Fit2Standard Journey

Across many rollouts, one pattern consistently stands out: the results achieved in the final rollout directly depends on the effort put into the preparation phase.
Local Units‚Äô Preparation and the System Demo require relatively moderate effort but yet deliver a significant impact. When local teams commit early, approach it intentionally, the Fit2Standard workstream becomes organized, efficient, and transparent instead of reactive and cumbersome.
These early actions do more than simply initiate the process. They establish the tone, determine the pace, and build the foundation for a successful and scalable global template rollout.

***

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (2/3): Exposing the Myths - What Analysis and Validation Really Reveal
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens G√∂tz
***

 In global rollout and standardization programs, differing local narratives are not just a source of friction‚Äîthey‚Äôre an important signal. When some teams argue their processes are ‚Äútoo special‚Äù to standardize, and others assume headquarters will override local needs anyway, they‚Äôre really expressing concerns about relevance, control, and risk. Almost every country or business unit sees its processes as unique, and that perception shapes expectations long before a rollout begins.

Rather than treating these positions as resistance, they can be used as early input: they highlight where standards need clearer value articulation, where flexibility is required, and where local practices might actually enrich the global design. The challenge is less about eliminating these narratives and more about channeling them into structured dialogue, so that priorities are set on evidence and impact‚Äînot on assumptions or fear of losing autonomy.

This is where the Local System Analysis and Template Validation play a role far beyond its technical nature. They expose uncertainties, challenge long-held assumptions and replace organizational doubts with facts.

Local System Analysis: A Mirror, Not a Microscope

Contrary to popular belief, Local System Analysis is not a simple chasing of the potential gaps. It is rather a mirror held to reflect where the processes truly differ, where legal obligations are dictating exceptions and where the variations are supported simply because it was always done in a certain way.
This phase aids to depict the following truths about the local processes:

Uniqueness is not always the case: when the local teams examine their processes with the template, many cases reveal themselves as standard functionalities.

Identified gaps may not necessarily be an issue:  some differences are simply outdated practices; some are transitional behaviors inherited from legacy systems, and some are even local strengths.

Real complexities are discovered: often complexities are the result of historical decisions, internal habits and interpretations rather than legal requirements.

By documenting these findings systematically, the organization gains clarity on a different more granular level than during the preparation phase.

Template Validation: Turning Narratives Into Navigable Decisions

If Local System Analysis reflects the truth of local operations, the Template Validation is where that truth is validated and made usable.

This step addresses the large volume of gaps and conviction that otherwise might not be possible. Through systematic assessment each gap is examined against the following criteria:

  • Is it legally required or simply preferred?
  • Is this solved through configuration or enhancement?
  • Is the need essential or historical?
  • Does it support strategy or merely habit?

What once appeared as a matter of concern becomes a clear set of categories and complexity becomes structured. The Template Validation it helps to gain clarity and the same understanding.

 

Confidence through Clarity:

By the time these two phases conclude, an organization experiences a shift ‚Äì not in the processes but in the narrative. Discussions become more evidence-based, relationships between the local and central teams become more balanced, and the atmosphere becomes more cooperative and fosters organizational honesty, making the global rollouts sustainable rather than fragile.

***

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (3/3): From Decision to Delivery - Final Structuring Steps
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens G√∂tz
***

As organizations progress through the Fit2Standard approach, the early phases ‚Äî preparation, system demonstration, analysis, and validation ‚Äî create a shared understanding between central and local teams. By the time these steps are completed, the functional discussions are largely settled, and key questions have been clarified.

The final two phases of the methodology, Review & Approval and Upload & Planning, play an essential role in translating this clarity into a manageable, well-governed delivery plan:

 

 

They are not about re-opening discussions but about organizing what has already been agreed, ensuring that decisions move into implementation in a structured and traceable way.

Review & Approval: Concluding the Decision-Making Process

Review and Approval serve as the formal closure of the analysis and validation work. Its purpose is straightforward: to consolidate findings, confirm decisions, and provide the governance needed before any building activities begin.

The process typically starts with the creation of a clear, focused and easy-understandable decision pack. This includes the validated gaps, their impact assessments, any compliance considerations, and the recommended solutions. Presenting this information in a structured form enables the Product Owner and relevant stakeholders to make well-informed decisions without revisiting previous discussions.

The Product Owner then classifies each item:

  • What will be addressed within the global template
  • What falls out of scope
  • What requires escalation or further review

Where necessary, management approval is most likely required, particularly for items with regulatory or financial implications. The result is an approved decision log ‚Äî a transparent record of what will move forward, on what priority, and under which ownership.

This phase ensures that the project enters delivery with alignment, documentation, and clear governance, avoiding ambiguity or conflicting interpretations in the program.

Upload & Planning: Turning Decisions Into an Actionable Backlog

Once approvals are secured, the next step is to translate decisions into the project‚Äôs operational structure. Upload and Planning focus on transferring requirements into a backlog, preparing the template team for the actual implementation, and organizing the work to ensure that the delivery can begin without delays.

Each approved requirement is transformed into a backlog item (typically into a user story or into a change request), supported by acceptance criteria and relevant attachments. This provides the template team with the context needed to build accurately and efficiently.

During this phase, dependencies are also identified. These can include cross-functional impacts or technical constraints. Pointing these early out allows the project to plan realistically and reduces potential friction during design and build.

A formal handover session typically concludes with the phase. The rollout team presents the backlog to the template delivery team, reviewing business context and supporting materials. This ensures a consistent understanding of the scope and reduces the risk of misinterpretation und unclarity during the implementation.

With this, the program transitions from analysis into execution, supported by a structured plan, a clear set of priorities, and a well-informed delivery team, which is key to successful implementation.

Integration With Earlier Fit2Standard Work

These closing phases do not stand alone; they connect directly to the work already completed:

  • Local System Analysis identified and documented the relevant gaps.
  • Template Validation confirmed their relevance and categorized them.
  • Review & Approval converted these outcomes into final decisions.
  • Upload & Planning operationalized those decisions and prepared them for delivery.

Together, they form a logical and predictable transition from understanding requirements to executing them effectively.

A Structured Conclusion to the Fit2Standard Cycle

Global S/4HANA rollouts benefit most when clarity and governance accompany each phase of Fit2Standard. The Review & Approval and Upload & Planning phases provide this discipline. They ensure that the investment made in analysis and validation results in a well-organized backlog and a focused, transparent delivery plan.

In many organizations, these final steps make the difference between a rollout that proceeds smoothly and one that becomes rather reactive or fragmented. By closing the Fit2Standard cycle with a structured, traceable, and thoughtfully prepared handover to delivery teams, the organizations are enabled with a consistent execution across their subsidiaries and business units.

entry.title: Custom Situation Handling in Quality Management: Get Notified when an Inspection Lot is Created
entry.content:
Use Case: ‚ÄúCreate Custom Situation Type for notifying users when an inspection lot is created‚Äù.

Even though standards apps are available which can be used to check the inspections lots created for the day. However, due to nature of the business role/responsibilities and frequency of inspection process, some users(customers) want the system to notify them via situation handling.

This blog is a detailed guide for configuring a custom situation type in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to notify users when an inspection lot is created. Here's a structured summary of the key concepts and steps:

Objective

Enable notifications (SAP Fiori home screen + email) when an inspection lot is created using Situation Handling ‚Äì Extended Framework.

Solution Overview

  • Customizable for specific business scenarios.
  • Notifications triggered by events (e.g., inspection lot creation).
  • Delivered via SAP Fiori and email.

After setting up the custom situation type, users will be able to receive notifications on their SAP home screen and via email.

 

 

Prerequisites

Apps Required:

  • Manage Situation Objects
  • Manage Teams and Responsibilities
  • Manage Responsibility Contexts
  • Manage Situation Scenarios
  • Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended

Roles Required:

  • BR_BUSINESS_PROCESS_SPEC
  • BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
  • BR_ADMINISTRATOR
  • BR_BPC_EXPERT
  • BR_EMPLOYEE
  • BR_EMPLOYEE_MAINTENANC

These are default SAP roles. Custom roles depend on the authorization concept can be set-up in the specific system.

Step-by-Step Setup

Key Concept: Basic steps for creating a custom situation type in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are outlined in the pictures below. Users can create their own situation use cases with the extended framework for Situation Handling.  The extended framework offers three new configuration apps: Mange Situation Objects, Manage Situation Scenarios, and Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended.

The following image illustrates the activities associated with the respective applications.

 

Step 1: Create Situation Objects

With this app, users can model business objects that facilitate Situation Handling. A situation object connects existing application artifacts, such as CDS views, events, and actions, which serve as the foundation for establishing situation use cases.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Objects‚Äù app.

  • Create object ID (Picture 1)
  • Use CDS view I_INSPECTIONLOT.
  • Define Structures: (Picture 2)
    • Set semantic keys and personal data fields. (Picture 2)
  • Define Events, anchor and trigger objects (Picture 3). In general anchor and trigger object are established on the situation scenario level. e.g. Inspection lot creation
    • In this situation, the anchor and trigger are the same, i.e. the inspection lot
  • Define navigation & actions (Picture 4 &5). The event corresponds to the modeled object created earlier and can be used as triggers.

(Picture 1)

(Picture 2)

(Picture 3)

(Picture 4)

While generic IDs like NAV01 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and navigation target, e.g. YY1_NAV_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

(Picture 5)

While generic IDs like ACT1 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and Action, e.g. YY1_ACT_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

For further information refer to : https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d973eb6d464d4dce84f354b9668ef43c.html

 

Step 2: Create Responsibility Context

Manage Responsibility Contexts in SAP lets you view, use, and extend standard or custom contexts that define who is responsible for business tasks across workflows and situation handling. A responsibility context links specific business processes or objects (like inspection lot) with rules or teams to determine the responsible agents. You can extend standard contexts or create custom ones with tailored agent rules, enabling precise assignment of responsibilities to individuals or teams for better workflow and process management.

A team is defined in the app ‚ÄòManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äô whereas Team category is assigned in the app ‚ÄôManage Responsibility Context‚Äô. Using configuration ‚ÄòDefine Team Types‚Äô the mapping of team type and team category is done.

  • Create team in ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibilities‚Äù.
  • Define context in ‚ÄúManage Responsibility Contexts‚Äù.(Picture 7 &'8)
    • Add team category. (Picture 6 &'8)

Step 3: Create Situation Scenario

This app helps to create your own scenarios for extended object-based situations. These are situations that occur for a specific business object, like an inspection lot. A situation scenario is a technical description of a business scenario and serves as the foundation for defining multiple use cases in the form of situation templates. 

A situation scenario consists of one anchor object and one/more trigger objects. An anchor object is the object that is affected by a situation, such as an inspection lot. A trigger object creates an impact that results in situation instances for the anchor object, such as creation of an inspection lot.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Scenarios‚Äù.

  • Define scenario ID, type (Object-based), and structure (CDS). (Picture 9)
  • Select the anchor object and anchor object structure (Picture 9)
  • Add the instance key, i.e. the anchor object. (Picture 10)
  • Define List page layout (Picture 10).
  • Define general and specific actions. (Picture 11)
  • Define parameters for situation triggers (Picture 12 & 13) ‚Äì It can be triggered via events (e.g when inspection lot is created) or using batch jobs (e.g. running batch jobs every few hours to notify users on the created inspection lots)
  • Define Situation Page (Picture 13A) - Here user can select the field which should be populated in the notification details.

Step 4: Create Team

This app allows users to manage teams, define responsibilities, and assign functions to team members in the Responsibility Management section. By using responsibility definitions and member functions, you can identify the members (recipients) who are responsible for workflows, business scenarios, and handling situations.

Use ‚ÄúManage Teams and Responsibility‚Äù.

  • Assign team type. The category will be automatically filled. (Picture 14)
  • Responsibility parameters will be populated automatically based on the configuration ‚ÄòAssign Custom Responsibility Definition‚Äô SSCUI- 102159 (e.g., plant)
  • Assign member functions for notification routing. The members are also not only for receiving notifications, but also for those who gets to see situations/situation instances in the app ‚ÄòMy Situations ‚Äì Extended‚Äô

(Picture 14)

Step 5: Create Situation Template

Situation templates are used to define and standardize the monitoring of specific business exceptions or critical situations. These templates act as blueprints for different situation types.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Define template ID, scenario, and triggers. (Picture 15)
  • Choose if user needs the instances to be kept (Picture 16)
  • Set General Actions (Picture 17)
  • Define situation Triggers (Picture 18)
    • Set conditions and filters. (Picture 19, 20) e.g. Inspection type
    • Configure display and notification texts. (Picture 21)
    • Optional: define navigation actions. (Picture 22)

Step 6: Create Situation Type

Situation types describe a business situation that defines how a situation instance is triggered and who is informed about it. In the extended framework for Situation Handling, the configuration of a situation type also includes the definition of actions for solving a situation. These situations are automatically detected and addressed by identifying and handling critical events or exceptions within business processes. Situation types are derived from templates and offer customization options for conditions, notifications, responsible users, and informative texts for users. Upon activation, they generate situation instances that promptly notify the designated users, thereby enhancing process efficiency and decision-making.

Use ‚ÄúManage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended‚Äù.

  • Create situation type by copying the template created in the previous step.
  • Enable status. (Picture 23)

Step 7: Test

  • Create inspection lot manually or via goods receipt.
  • Check notifications
