entry.title: How to copy text from sales order to Purchase Requisition, Purchase Order and Inbound Delivery?
entry.content:
Ever wondered how to ensure that important text information from your sales documents flows seamlessly into your purchase documents? In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how to copy sales order text into a purchase requisition, purchase order, and subsequently into the inbound delivery. This ensures that critical notes, requirements, or instructions are carried forward across the transaction chain ‚Äî reducing errors and improving collaboration between sales and procurement teams.

Why Text Flow Matters:

  • Consistency: Keeps customer requirements visible throughout the process.
  • Efficiency: Avoids manual re-entry of notes, saving time.
  • Accuracy: Reduces risk of miscommunication between departments.
  • Compliance: Ensures contractual or regulatory text is not lost in transition.

How Text Flow Works: 

SAP text determination procedures define how text is copied between documents. The configuration involves:

  • Text Types: Define categories like ‚ÄúCustomer Notes,‚Äù ‚ÄúDelivery Instructions,‚Äù or ‚ÄúInternal Comments.‚Äù
  • Text Determination Procedure: Assigns rules for which text types should be copied from sales orders to purchase requisitions, purchase orders, and inbound deliveries.
  • Access Sequence: Determines the source of the text (e.g., sales order header, item level).
  • Control Settings: Decide whether text is copied automatically, editable, or mandatory.

Note: Copying of SO item text to PO item can be done using configuration. For copying of SO header text to PR or PO header text, you may need use enhancement IF_EX_ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST method.

Configuration Path:

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Text Control ‚Üí Define Text Types‚Üí Sales Document Item

Copy and rename new sales order item text ID as required.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Requisition‚Üí Texts for Purchase Requisitions ‚Üí Define Copying Rules

Define Text type that would like to use link the sales order text.  

Define Copying rules for text linkage. Here the source object is Sales Order and Source text is the sales order item text that you would like to copy from sales order.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Order‚Üí Texts for Purchase Orders ‚Üí Define Copying Rules for Item Texts

Define Copying rules for text linkage similar to purchase requistion. Here the source object is purchase requistion and Source text is the purchase requisition item text that you would like to copy from purchase requisition. You may also define sales order as source object if you plan to copy direcly from sales order.

SPRO ‚Üí SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Logistics Execution ‚Üí Shipping ‚Üí Basic Shipping Functions‚Üí Text Control ‚Üí Define Text Types

Here you need to define text type, access sequence and assign the Text Determination procedure to the delivery Item Category. 

You can use existing header text ID or create a new header text ID as per the requirement. Assign the text ID to the determination procedure.

For copying PO header text to inbound delivery header text, create an access sequence and assign the Text object EKKO to the purchase order header text ID.

Assign the Text Determination procedure to the Inbound Delivery Type.

Similarly, for copying Purchase order item text to inbound delivery Item text, create or use an existing delivery item text. Assign the text ID to Text determination procedure. Create an access sequence and assign the purchase order text object EKPO and the purchase order text ID to the newly created access sequence. Assign the Text Determination procedure to the Inbound delivery Item Category.

Now it's ready for copying texts from sales order item ‚Üí purchase requisition ‚Üí  purchase order ‚Üí inbound delivery.

Conclusion: Text determination ensures critical information flows seamlessly across teams, improving collaboration and reducing errors. By configuring text determination procedure to copy texts from sales documents to purchase documents, organizations can guarantee that critical notes, requirements, and instructions remain visible across the entire supply chain transactions.

entry.title: How to Scale AI: Best Practices for modernizing data and integrating processes with SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: Best Practices for modernizing data and integrating processes with SAP Cloud ERP

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data‚Äîgetting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what‚Äôs involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

J√ºrgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. J√ºrgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI‚Äôs potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They‚Äôre also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we‚Äôve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI‚Äôs potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization‚Äôs own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization‚Äôs data structures‚Äîits master data and system architecture‚Äîneed to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP‚Äôs strategy for scalable AI

SAP‚Äôs approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

Figure 3: How to allow AI to understand your business safely

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP‚Äôs agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems‚Äî provided those systems have been integrated and their data‚Äôs been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you‚Äôll have access to harmonized data‚Äîbut you won‚Äôt yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you‚Äôll be able to join up business processes across applications‚Äîbut not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they‚Äôre not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP‚Äôs AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP‚Äôs integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they‚Äôll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It‚Äôs a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll‚Äîwhich aren‚Äôt integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally‚Äîalways leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP‚Äôs enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP‚Äôs vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: Invoice Submission to the Singapore Tax Authority: How to Automate Invoice Note Filling in XML Files
entry.content:
Are you a GST-registered business in Singapore subject to the GST InvoiceNow Requirement? If so, you need to submit invoice data electronically to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). This may include providing invoice notes in XML files submitted to IRAS. This blog provides guidance on how you can automate this step.

A few quick notes:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is the solution to support GST InvoiceNow requirements. For an overview, check out this blog: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Singapore GST InvoiceNow.
  • This blog applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP S/4HANA, and SAP ERP.
  • This blog quotes information from some IRAS guidelines. The quoted information is accurate as of the publication date of the blog. As these IRAS guidelines are subject to change, we recommend checking the latest versions for the most current information.

 

What Is an Invoice Note?

Here‚Äôs the definition of invoice note from TX2 - Annex - Data Specifications, which can be downloaded from here:

A textual note that gives unstructured information that is relevant to the Invoice as a whole such as the reason for any correction or assignment note in case the invoice has been factored.

An invoice note is displayed in one of these XML elements, depending on the invoice type:

  • ubl:Invoice / cbc:Note for invoices
  • ubl:CreditNote / cbc:Note for credit notes

IRAS specifies the scenarios where an invoice note is mandatory, such as credit notes and self-billing invoices. For certain special scenarios, IRAS prescribes their note texts. For example, according to the e-Tax Guide ‚ÄúAdopting GST InvoiceNow Requirement for GST-registered Businesses (First Edition)‚Äù, you must include this exact note text in self-billing invoices:

The invoice is a Buyer Created Tax Invoice. The tax shown is your output tax due to the Comptroller of GST.

 

The Challenge: Automating Beyond the Standard

To include an invoice note in a submitted XML file, you need to enter the note text in a specific source document field. For those scenarios that require specific note texts, it would be a great time-saver if the system can fill in them automatically. The standard solution already does this for these scenarios:

  • Self-billing invoices
  • Customer invoices with the GST category code SRCA-S (Customer accounting supply made by supplier)
  • Supplier invoices with the GST category code TXCA (Standard-rated purchases of prescribed goods subject to customer accounting)

What about other scenarios? Manually entering invoice notes is really time-consuming and prone to error.

 

The Solution: BAdI to the Rescue

You can define your own logic for populating invoice notes using the following Business Add-Ins (BAdIs):

ProductBAdI
  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • SAP ERP
EDOC_ADAPTOR: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionEDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method

In this blog, we'll show you how to create a BAdI implementation that populates invoice notes for customer invoices (eDocument type: SGC5C_INV) in these scenarios based on the tax code:

ScenarioInvoice Note Text Prescribed by IRASTax Code You Use
Gross Margin SchemeThe transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.S1
Approved Marine Fuel Trader SchemeThe Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.Z1
Discounted Sale Price SchemeThe transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.Z2

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Sample BAdI Implementation in SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ERP

Step 1: Create a customer package.

Some objects are created when you create a BAdI implementation. To transport these objects across a customer landscape, create a customer package or choose an existing customer package.

Step 2: Create an enhancement implementation.

In this example, we create an implementation named ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 by doing the following:

  1. Call up the SE19 transaction.
  2. Select the New BAdI radio button in the Create Implementation section and enter ES_EDOCUMENT in the Enhancement Spot field. Choose Create.



  3. Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the enhancement implementation name and Implementation: eDocument Adaptor Singapore as the short text. Choose Continue.



    When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.

  4. In the window that appears next, do the following:
    • Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the BAdI implementation name.
    • Enter ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the implementation class.
    • Select the BAdI definition EDOC_ADAPTOR.

  5. Choose Continue. When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.
  6. Activate your changes.
  7. Expand the tree for the BAdI implementation you just created. Double-click Filter Values.



  8. In the filter values details on the right, choose Create Filter Combination. 



  9. In the Choose Filter dialog, select COUNTRY. Choose Continue.
  10. Double-click the COUNTRY filter.
  11. In the Display Filter Value dialog, enter SG as Value 1 and select = as Comparator 1. Choose Continue.



    The filter combination you just created looks like this: 



Step 3: Update the ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 class.

  1. Call up the SE24 transaction.
  2. Enter the object type ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5. Choose Change.



  3. Double-click the method IF_EDOC_ADAPTOR~SET_OUTPUT_DATA.



  4. Add the sample code below into this method:
        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.‚Äã


5. Save and activate your changes.

 

Guidance for Customers Using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

You need to add the sample code below into the SET_OUTPUT_DATA method of the EDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud BAdI:

Tip: 
For a step-by-step guide on how to implement this BAdI, check out the following blog:

                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.

 

Wrapping Up

Hope this blog is helpful for you. We'd love to hear feedback from you. Feel free to share comments below. Let's learn from each other!

entry.title: S/4HANA Logistics: Solving the "Not Possible to Determine Shipping Data" Block in STO
entry.content:
S/4HANA Logistics: Solving the "Not Possible to Determine Shipping Data" Block in STO

Published By :-

Er. Pratik Das

B.Tech in Mechanical Engineering

SAP Functional Consultant / SAP Coach

 Published: December 2025 Target Audience: S/4HANA Functional Consultants (MM/SD)

.........................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................

One of the most common tickets we see during the integration testing phase of an S/4HANA rollout is the missing "Shipping" tab in the Stock Transport Order (STO). When you check the logs, you‚Äôre hit with the hard error: "Not possible to determine shipping data for material &" (Message no. 06280).

In S/4HANA, the integration between Purchasing and Logistics Execution is significantly more rigid due to the Business Partner (BP) approach and the mandatory requirement for synchronized Master Data. If you are facing this error, the system is essentially telling you that the handshake between the Supplying Plant and the Receiving Plant is broken at the organizational level.

Below is a technical deep dive into the four critical configuration pillars required to resolve this.

  1. The BP Linkage (The S/4HANA Foundation)

In ECC, we dealt with Vendors and Customers. In S/4HANA, we deal with Business Partners. For an STO to function, the Receiving Plant must be represented as a Customer BP.

  • Verification: Ensure the BP representing the Receiving Plant is extended to the Sales Area (Sales Org/Dist. Channel/Division) associated with the Supplying Plant.
  • The "Link": In the Supplier Role (FLVN01), navigate to the Purchasing Data tab. Go to Additional Purchasing Data and ensure the Plant field is populated with the Supplying Plant ID. This is a mandatory link for the system to recognize the internal procurement relationship.
  1. Plant-Level Shipping Configuration (V_T001W)

This is the most common point of failure. The system needs a specific mapping to know which "Sales Entity" the Supplying Plant belongs to.

  • Path: IMG > Materials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Order > Set up Stock Transport Order > Define Shipping Data for Plants.
  • Action: 1. Select the Supplying Plant: Maintain the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, and Division. 2. Select the Receiving Plant: Ensure the Customer Number (the BP created in Step 1) is assigned here.
  • Note: If the Customer Number is not assigned to the Receiving Plant in this table, the "Shipping" tab will never trigger in the PO.
  1. Material Master Extension (Sales Views)

It sounds fundamental, but it is often overlooked during mass data uploads (LTMC/Migrate Your Data).

  • The Requirement: The material must be extended to the Sales Org/Dist. Channel of the Supplying Plant.
  • Key Fields: * Loading Group: (Sales: General/Plant Data) ‚Äì Mandatory for shipping point determination later.
    • Material Tax Classification: Must be maintained, or the delivery creation will fail downstream.
    • Availability Check (Group): Ensure this is maintained to allow the system to calculate the delivery date.
  1. Delivery Type & Checking Rule Assignment

The system needs to know which document type to trigger (e.g., NL for Intra-company or NLCC for Inter-company).

  • Path: IMG > Materials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Order > Set up Stock Transport Order > Assign Delivery Type and Checking Rule.
  • Logic: Look for your PO Document Type (usually UB or NB) and your Supplying Plant.
  • Common Fix: Ensure that for your combination, the Delivery Type field is not blank. For S/4HANA Inter-company, this is typically NLCC.

Debugging Checklist for the Field

If you have performed the above and still face Message 06280, check these "hidden" culprits:

  1. Sales Area Alignment: Is the Sales Area assigned to the Supplying Plant in V_T001W exactly the same one the Material is extended to? A mismatch in Division is a frequent silent killer.
  2. Customer/BP Status: Check if the Customer BP has a "Central Deletion Flag" or "Sales Block." S/4HANA is much stricter about master data status than ECC.
  3. Ship-to Party Assignment: Does the Customer BP have a valid Ship-to Party (SH) partner function maintained for the specific Sales Area?

Conclusion

Message 06280 is a "Gatekeeper" error. It prevents you from proceeding because the foundational SD data is missing. By ensuring the BP is correctly mapped to the Plant and the Material is extended to the correct Sales Org, you can resolve this and enable the full Logistics Execution flow.

entry.title: BehaviorInvocationException: Too few values in second queue in function useOneAsMany
entry.content:
Problem Statement

In SAP CPI Message Mapping, I faced a OneAsMany violation due to mismatched occurrences between two source fields:

  • Company Code ‚Üí Occurrence = 1

  • PRODUCTTAXITEM ‚Üí Occurrence = 2
    So basically, due to difference in context change, I was not able to use it in value mapping where the target field occurrence is also 2 times, due to this if i use it without OneasMany, it is throwing error : target field require value for it.

This resulted in the following OneAsMany rules being violated:

Rule 1: Input 1 should not contain repeating values in the same context.

Business requirement was to:

  • Increase the context of Company Code

  • Match it with the number of PRODUCTTAXITEM occurrences

  • Repeat only the first Company Code value for all PRODUCTTAXITEM contexts.

    Groovy code used is as follows:

    import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

    // Function name must match the name used in Message Mapping UI
    def void replicateCompanyCode(
    String[] companyCode,
    String[] productTaxItem,
    Output companyCodeOut,
    MappingContext context) {

    // Guard checks
    if (companyCode == null || companyCode.length == 0 ||
    productTaxItem == null || productTaxItem.length == 0) {
    companyCodeOut.addSuppress()
    return
    }

    // Take only the first Company Code
    String firstCompanyCode = companyCode[0]

    // Create context based on PRODUCTTAXITEM count
    for (int i = 0; i < productTaxItem.length; i++) {
    companyCodeOut.addValue(firstCompanyCode)
    companyCodeOut.addContextChange()
    }
    }

entry.title: How to Take SAP‚Äôs New Performance-Based Certification Exams
entry.content:
Beginning in November 2025, SAP updated parts of its certification program by introducing scenario-based assessments exams. These exams replace the traditional proctored, multiple-choice format and are designed to better reflect real-world use cases.

In this post, I walk you through what has changed, how the new exam formats work, what to expect from AI-assisted and expert-reviewed assessments, and what this means for certification renewal‚Äîbased on my own experience retaking the SAP BTP Solution Architect exam.

Some certifications are now available only through this new approach like:

With this new format, there is less focus on memorizing detailed information. Instead, candidates demonstrate their knowledge by solving practical scenarios. You may complete tasks using AI-assisted tools or submit video-based responses that are reviewed by SAP experts later.

 You can explore available certifications by logging into SAP Learning at https://learning.sap.com and navigating to the Get Certified section.

To identify the exam format, click on the exam you are interested in. On the above right side of the exam page, the presence of ‚ÄúSchedule Exam‚Äù indicates that the exam is delivered through a third-party proctoring service:

If after clicking on the exam you see "Go to Certification Exam" on the top right ,it is on new scenario-based :

According to the SAP latest announcement, all SAP exams (by the end of March 2026) will be switched to this self-managed new performance-based exam.

If you choose the AI option with this new approach, the results are reviewed automatically in real time right after your submission. You can see your failure or success immediately. If you fail, you will receive the detailed analysis of your response by AI which can help you with your next exam try.

If you choose to submit videos, it will be scored by experts within 10 business days.

This analyzing session will not be available to you in your next log on, please make sure to review that before missing that session to help you to focus on your weakness for your next same exam try.

How real skills are used in scenario based

Practical

Certification exams mimic real tasks, such as configuring real SAP systems, building processes, coding, or delivering SAP solutions based on a case study.

Open book

Leverage all kinds of resources to complete the exams, just as you would on an actual SAP project. 

AI-enabled

Access AI support, such as SAP Joule for Consultants or any other AI Large Language Models (LLMs).

System-based assessment

Learners have the opportunity to complete practical tasks in time-limited SAP system simulations, testing their ability to perform specific tasks or operations.

Scenario-based assessment

Learners engage in time-limited role-play with an AI avatar, delivering SAP solutions, advising on architecture, and performing simulations.

A subscription to SAP Learning Hub includes 4 SAP certification exam attempts in one year or you can buy certification attempts (LINK).

At the time of writing this blog, to renew a certification for an additional year, you must have an active SAP Learning Hub subscription to complete the required renewal assessment:

If your certification is still valid, the renewal process does not require taking a performance-based or scenario-based exam. This exam formats apply only when pursuing a new certification, provided that the certification has already transitioned to the new scenario-based or practical exam approach.

Recently I decided to retake SAP BTP Solution Architect rather than renew through leaning Hub assessment to help me to write this post.

Here I walk you through high level steps:

First, you find your desired Exam page and click on the link:

https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-professional-solution-architect-sap-btp

Next you choose ‚ÄúGo to Certification Exam‚Äù:

Then, you see the screen below and after clicking the box for ‚ÄúTerms and Conditions‚Äù you can hit ‚Äústart Certification Exam‚Äù that will use one of your exam attempts credits and you have 24 hours to do the exam, or you lose one of your exams attempts credits:

As shown above, you have up to four exam attempts within a one-year period to achieve certification. If all four attempts are unsuccessful, you must wait 12 months before retaking the same exam.

Next, you will see the page below, which I chose AI for my Role-play then click on ‚ÄúAgree and get Started‚Äù:

Then you see the next screen and after allowing your camera, you will be able to start the exam by clicking on Start button:

Important note: Once you start the exam session, the assessment typically takes around 20‚Äì30 minutes and is conducted through an AI-powered chat experience using Yoodli technology. Before clicking on Start button, it is strongly recommended that you thoroughly review the case study PDF provided as part of the exam and prepare your solution in advance, for example in a notepad or word document, which you can reference during the AI role-play conversation.

This exam uses Yoodli technology and does not require any software installation. If you would like to familiarize yourself with the format, you can create a free account at https://yoodli.ai/ and practice using sample role-play scenarios.

During the exam, an interactive chat window will appear, allowing you to follow the conversation and view a live transcript of the AI avatar‚Äôs responses.

Areas Where There Is Still Room for Improvement

While this new exam approach is a positive step forward, there are still areas that could benefit from further refinement. In particular, it would help to ensure that participants clearly understand the scenario or practice environment and easily find sufficient time to review the requirements and prepare their responses before starting the session.

Compared to traditional proctored exams, there are also open questions around identity verification. It is not yet clear how this new format consistently confirms that the individual completing the assessment is the same person who registered for the exam.

In addition, with the new exam approach, candidates do not currently receive an automatic email notification showing pass or fail status, scores, or a detailed performance analysis.

Hopefully, the SAP certification team will continue refining this model so it better aligns with the rigor and value traditionally associated with proctored exams in these areas.
